channel.title: Bossy Lobster
channel.description: A blog by Danny Hermes; musing on tech, mathematics, etc.

item.title: Preventing PostgreSQL Deadlocks in Go
item.description:
I've been writing a library for running PostgreSQL migrations in Go. One of the primary pieces of advice I keep coming across is

Beware of lock queues, use lock timeouts

In other words, each migration stage should happen instantaneously (or almost instantaneously). For real-time applications, if a migration runs "for …
item.dc:creator: Danny Hermes (dhermes@bossylobster.com)

item.title: A Threadsafe Connection Pool for Requests

item.title: Decoding HTTP/2 and gRPC
item.description: In order to learn a bit more about how both the TCP and HTTP/2 protocols work, I recently created the tcp-h2-describe reverse proxy in Python. I was excited about some of the insights I was able to glean from the process, in particular a full example tracing a connection …
item.dc:creator: Danny Hermes (dhermes@bossylobster.com)

item.title: Type Guards for Union Types in TypeScript
item.description:
In my day job at Blend, I write a lot of TypeScript1. One great feature of TypeScript is the ability to specify an enum with a finite set of values as a union type:

type Coordinate = 'x' | 'y'

which then gives compile time checking for values of this type …

item.title: Attack of Ruby Stack Traces

item.title: Learn You a LAPACK for Great Good
item.description:
Linear Algebra is an incredibly powerful tool. A joke among mathematicians is that the only way we can solve a hard problem is to boil it down to Linear Algebra1. Harnessing the numerical power of Linear Algebra has been done via LAPACK for the last 40+ years.

In my …

item.title: Graduated
item.description:
After five years, I'm excited to say I've finished my PhD. I certainly learned a lot and met a lot of great people along the way.

One of the biggest lessons I learned was about myself: I need to say no more often. I continued to say yes, to side …

item.title: Installing Python on OS X
item.description:
Caveat: I stopped using a Mac for my development machine way back in the fall of 2014. You probably shouldn't listen to me.

What Not to Do

The first rule of using Python on any operating system: don't use system Python. The OS relies on that Python, including the packages …

Even three years into a PhD in Applied Math (i.e. numerics), I still managed to learn something by diving in and trying …

item.title: Newton's (Method's) Failure
item.description:
Finding zeros of any old function is a common task, and using Newton's method is one of the best tools for carrying out this task. I've even written an old post that used this method.

However, Newton's method loses some of it's luster around repeated roots. Consider the iteration

x …

item.title: How Many Ways to Make a (Football) Score
item.description:
While watching today's Seahawks-Vikings game, my wife asked:

How did the Seahawks score 9 points? Did they get a field goal and miss an extra point after a touchdown?

I had been head down coding and didn't know the answer. I quickly jotted down the possibilities (like solving the coin-change …

item.title: An Interesting Bug
item.description:
A fairly common interview question is

What is the "hardest" bug you've dealt with?

item.title: A Python Metaclass for "extra bad" errors in Google App Engine
item.description:
So now here we are, having tried to handle errors in Google App Engine...and failed all because silly DeadlineExceededError jumps over Exception in the inheritance chain and goes right for BaseException. How can we catch these in our handlers while staying Pythonic?

First and foremost, in the case of …
